Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: QTL Mapping Floral Trait Divergence and Reproductive Isolation between a Jaltomata (Solanaceae) Species Pair
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study aims to identify genes controlling floral trait differences between two species of Jaltomata, a florally diverse genus that is closely related to the economically important genus Solanum (which includes tomato and potato), and to examine whether these genes may also contribute to reproductive barriers between these species. Differences in floral traits are well known to reduce reproduction between species when they attract different pollinators; this study also addresses how such differences may affect success of other reproductive stages, including the survival of hybrids. The flowering plants (Angiosperms) form the foundation of agriculture as well as many of the Earth's ecosystems. This study will advance our understanding of how differences in floral traits may first arise, and how those differences may reduce or prevent reproduction between distinct species. This project will also provide research experiences for undergraduates, including those from groups underrepresented in STEM fields.

This work will employ Quantitative Trait Locus (QTL) Mapping to identify genomic regions associated with floral trait differences and multiple reproductive barriers between two species by genotyping an existing hybrid population that has already been phenotyped for these traits. These genomic regions will help determine the genetic basis and evolutionary history shaping floral traits and reproductive barriers in this system. In combination with existing gene expression data from relevant floral and reproductive tissues, the study will also identify candidate genes controlling these processes. These are key steps in understanding the mapping between genotype and phenotype, which is of fundamental importance in both basic and applied biology. Ultimately, this work potentially will provide unique insights into the genetics and evolution of floral diversity, and the mechanistic role of this diversity in promoting speciation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study examined floral trait differences, and their underlying genetic basis, between two closely related species that nonetheless differ in many elements of flower shape, size, and color. Three features make flowers an excellent model for addressing the processes that generate biodiversity: First they are remarkably variable across the angiosperms (the flowering plants); second, the general molecular framework responsible for initiating the development of flowers has been described; and, third, flowers likely significantly contributed to the success of the angiosperms overall, for example via their interactions with other organisms like pollinators. However, while much is known about the developmental and genetic underpinnings of flowers per se, we still lack an understanding of how floral trait differences first arise among closely related populations and species, and how this process might differ across different lineages. Here, an approach called Quantitative Trait Locus (QTL) mapping was used to identify genomic regions controlling floral and other reproductive trait differences between two closely related species of Jaltomata(Solanaceae, or tomato family). One species has flowers that are typical of bee-pollinated species, while the other has traits that indicate it is hummingbird-pollinated - including a very rare and enigmatic trait of darkly colored nectar. This study therefore aimed to identify the genetic changes leading to the emergence of rare traits, those associated with key ecological processes (i.e. plant-pollinator interactions), and more generally with the early stages of biological diversification. 

First, a large ‘mapping population’ of plants was developed, which consisted of the two parental species, their first-generation hybrid offspring, and nearly 300 second-generation hybrid offspring. Because each second-generation offspring inherits different regions of the genomes from the original two parents, this population allowed the examination of how alternative combinations of parental genetic variation affected floral and other reproductive trait values. Next, a high-throughput sequencing technique called Genotyping-By-Sequencing (GBS) was used to quantify genetic variation among individuals (i.e. to identify specific differences in DNA sequences). Then, statistical associations between specific genotypes and trait values were identified to locate specific portions of the genome that contain genes controlling the observed trait differences. Finally, in combination with other previously generated data, including the publicly available genome from the domesticated tomato as well as de novogene expression and comparative developmental data, these regions were narrowed down to specific candidate genes. 

Overall, these data (patterns of trait segregation within the population and identified QTL) support a relatively simple genetic basis underlying the majority of our examined floral traits. In particular, most traits appear to be additively controlled, with three to four associated QTL that have moderate to large phenotypic effects (i.e. changing the underlying DNA sequence produces a large change in the floral trait). In addition, correlations among trait values and patterns of QTL overlap suggest that many of the examined traits can change relatively independently, which is consistent with rapid floral trait divergence broadly observed within this study system. 

This study therefore identified regions of the genome, as well as candidate genes, associated with ecologically-relevant divergence in reproductive traits between two closely related species within the hyper-diverse tomato family. These data are valuable for understanding general mechanisms underlying phenotypic change, as well as identifying natural variation within wild relatives of multiple economically important plant species (e.g. domestic tomato, potato, pepper, petunia, tobacco). This research also contributed directly to training and professional development of two graduate students (one female), three undergraduate students (all female, one URM), and a lab technician, in plant biology, quantitative genetics, and the handling and interpretation of complex genomic datasets.
